title: Is The USD/SEK–DXY Correlation Broken?
text:
USD/SEK and DXY often move in the same direction. is frequently used as a proxy for the for those who don’t have access to trade DXY. As a matter of fact, since mid-June the correlation coefficient on a daily timeframe for the two instruments has been positive (meaning the 2 always move in the same direction) and the lowest reading since that date was +.46. However, today’s price action shows the 2 instruments diverging as the DXY is lower on the day and USD/SEK is higher.

Daily USD/SEK, USD

Source: Tradingview, FOREX.COM

If this correlation is to continue, there needs to be some type of mean reversion in order for the to line up again – so they can move together. Either the USD/SEK has to pull back or the DXY has to move higher, or a little of both.

On the 240-minute timeframe, has broken out of a flag pattern as prices could only pull back to the 38.2% Fibonacci retracement level from the low on September 24 to the highs on October 1. The target of a flag pattern is the distance of the flagpole added to the breakout point of the flag. In this case, the target is near 10.1500. However price doesn’t always move in a straight line and the current candle is putting in an inverted hammer (reversal indication). This may mean price could pull back and test the downward sloping trending of the flag, which is at 9.8756.

Source: Tradingview, FOREX.COM

As far as DXY is concerned on a 240-minute timeframe, price has pulled back from the recent highs and is currently testing horizontal resistance near 98.74. Ideally, this price should hold and bounce back above the rising trendline toward 99.20 if is going to continue higher.

4-Hour USD

Source: Tradingview, FOREX.COM

If DXY moves below 98.64, there is room for the USD to run lower. If the correlation remains intact, will have to pull back into the flag formation (with a false breakout) and test the bottom trendline of the flag pattern near 9.8115.
